title: Potential association between aortic stiffness, diastolic/systolic pressure time index and the balance between cardiac oxygen supply and demand: a word of caution
Selection of decoupling points in supply chains using a knowledge-based approach
container-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part B: Journal of Engineering Manufacture
items.abstract: <jats:p> As consumer affluence and desire for customized products and services at affordable prices and shorter lead times continue to accelerate, supply chain operators are facing increasing challenges of becoming both physically efficient (to enable the delivery of low cost) and flexible (to enable market-responsiveness). In order to meet these challenges, organizations are devising supply chain operation strategies that enable them to gain the benefits of physical efficiency of mass production and the customer focus of mass customization. A key to gaining these benefits lies in the selection of appropriate decoupling points in the supply chain. Decoupling points lie on the push—pull boundary. The selection of decoupling points requires knowledge from a range of different experts. The research reported in this paper used knowledge-based techniques to bring together knowledge from the viewpoints of different experts in the selection of decoupling points in supply chains. A knowledge model in the form of a network of production rules is presented. Results derived from applying the knowledge model to the case studies show similar trends to published literature. </jats:p>

title: Phenotypic and functional aspects of the neonatal immune system as related to the maternal dietary fatty acid supply of sows
Reliability of Lightguide Spectrophotometry (O2C®) for the Investigation of Skin Tissue Microvascular Blood Flow and Tissue Oxygen Supply in Diabetic and Nondiabetic Subjects
container-title: Journal of Diabetes Science and Technology
items.abstract: <jats:sec><jats:title>Background and Aims:</jats:title><jats:p> Skin microvascular assessment has progressed to an important evaluation in patients with diabetes mellitus. This study was done to evaluate a new device using micro-lightguide spectrophotometry in the assessment of skin microvascular function. </jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Material and Methods:</jats:title><jats:p> Twenty nondiabetic subjects (age 46.6 ± 14.8 years; mean ± SD) and 20 diabetic patients (age 59.4 ± 8.4 years) participated in repeated microvascular measurements using micro-lightguide spectrophotometry. This technique allows simultaneous, noninvasive measurement of microvascular blood flow and hemoglobin oxygenation (SO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>) at the same anatomical area in different tissue layers. A skin probe was placed on nonhairy skin at the thenar eminence of the left hand for the measurement of SO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, and the postischemic reactive hyperemia response (PRH) was measured in skin and underlying muscle tissue. </jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Results:</jats:title><jats:p> Repeated measurements in PRH revealed a good correlation at the superficial skin layer ( r = 0.97, p < 0.0001) with a coefficient of variation at 9.2 ± 1.7% and at the superficial muscle layer ( r = 0.80, p < 0.0002) with a coefficient of variation at 9.7 ± 1.5%. A slightly weaker correlation was observed for the SO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> measurement at the skin layer ( r = 0.69 ± p < 0.0001) with a coefficient of variation at 17.5 ± 3.8% and at the muscle layer ( r = 0.48; p = 0.0016) with a coefficient of variation at 18.1 ± 10.5%. </jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Conclusions:</jats:title><jats:p> Lightguide spectrophotometry is an easy, noninvasive, and reliable method for simultaneous measurement of superficial microvascular blood flow by laser Doppler fluxmetry and skin oxygenation by spectrophotometry. Further studies are required to clarify the validity of these measures in special patient populations such as diabetes mellitus with specified microvascular complications. </jats:p></jats:sec>

title: Design and Test Results for the PF Power Supply System of EAST
Circulatory limits to oxygen supply during an acute temperature increase in the Chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha)
container-title: American Journal of Physiology-Regulatory, Integrative and Comparative Physiology
items.abstract: <jats:p>This study was undertaken to provide a comprehensive set of data relevant to disclosing the physiological effects and possible oxygen transport limitations in the Chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha) during an acute temperature change. Fish were instrumented with a blood flow probe around the ventral aorta and catheters in the dorsal aorta and sinus venosus. Water temperature was progressively increased from 13°C in steps of 4°C up to 25°C. Cardiac output increased from 29 to 56 ml·min<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>·kg<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>between 13 and 25°C through an increase in heart rate (58 to 105 beats/min). Systemic vascular resistance was reduced, causing a stable dorsal aortic blood pressure, yet central venous blood pressure increased significantly at 25°C. Oxygen consumption rate increased from 3.4 to 8.7 mg·min<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>·kg<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup>during the temperature increase, although there were signs of anaerobic respiration at 25°C in the form of increased blood lactate and decreased pH. Arterial oxygen partial pressure was maintained during the heat stress, although venous oxygen partial pressure (Pv<jats:sub>O<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:sub>) and venous oxygen content were significantly reduced. Cardiac arrhythmias were prominent in three of the largest fish (>4 kg) at 25°C. Given the switch to anaerobic metabolism and the observation of cardiac arrhythmias at 25°C, we propose that the cascade of venous oxygen depletion results in a threshold value for Pv<jats:sub>O<jats:sub>2</jats:sub></jats:sub>of around 1 kPa. At this point, the oxygen supply to systemic and cardiac tissues is compromised, such that the oxygen-deprived and acidotic myocardium becomes arrhythmic, and blood perfusion through the gills and to the tissues becomes compromised.</jats:p>

title: Tonic B cell antigen receptor signals supply an NF-κB substrate for prosurvival BLyS signaling
Organic Amendment History and Crop Rotation Effects on Soil Nitrogen Mineralization Potential and Soil Nitrogen Supply in a Potato Cropping System
items.abstract: <jats:p>Crop management practices influence readily and potentially available N in soil. In this study, we evaluated the effects of organic amendment history and crop rotation on potentially mineralizable N (N<jats:sub>0</jats:sub>), mineralizable N pools, and field estimates of soil N supply in potato (<jats:italic>Solanum tuberosum</jats:italic> L.) production, and evaluated a suite of N availability measures to detect changes in these parameters. Preplant soil samples (top 15‐cm) were collected from the potato year of a rotation trial in Maine during 2004 and 2005. Treatments included three crop rotations, with and without a history of organic amendment [solid beef (<jats:italic>Bos taurus</jats:italic>) manure] application: PB, potato‐barley (<jats:italic>Hordeum vulgare</jats:italic> L.); PSPB, potato‐soybean [<jats:italic>Glycine max</jats:italic> (L.) Merr.]‐potato‐barley; and PSBA/T, potato‐soybean‐barley‐alfalfa (<jats:italic>Medicago sativa</jats:italic> L.)/timothy (<jats:italic>Phleum pratense</jats:italic> L.). The N<jats:sub>0</jats:sub> and mineralizable N pools were determined by aerobic incubation at 25°C and periodic leaching for 24 wk with a fixed‐<jats:italic>k</jats:italic> approach. On average, historically amended soil had 35% higher values of N<jats:sub>0</jats:sub>, and an 8% higher proportion of mineralizable N partitioned to the stable mineralizable N pool, compared with nonamended soil. Lower values of N<jats:sub>0</jats:sub>, mineralizable N pools and some measures of N availability were measured in PSBA/T compared with PB and PSPB rotations. All tested measures of N availability detected management‐induced changes in N<jats:sub>0</jats:sub> and mineralizable N pools. The preplant nitrate, UV absorbance of 0.01 <jats:italic>M</jats:italic> NaHCO<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> extract at 205 nm and particulate organic matter (POM)‐N were the best predictors of field‐based indices of soil N supply (<jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup> = 0.50 to 0.73). Management‐induced changes in the size and quality of mineralizable N should be considered in developing best N management programs through organic amendment application and crop rotations.</jats:p>
